articles.title: Free medical cover has revolutionised healthcare in India. So why is it ailing?
articles.trailText: Modi’s Ayushman Bharat scheme put hospital treatment within reach of tens of millions of Indians for the first time. But the government’s unpaid bills may derail the reforms
articles.summary: Ayushman Bharat, launched in 2018, offers free annual health cover of ₹500,000 per family at public and private hospitals, issuing 822m ABHA accounts and enabling nearly 100m admissions. Despite political goodwill, unpaid claims have soared past ₹1tn (₹4bn pending in Kerala alone), delaying reimbursements 4–6+ months, straining hospital cashflows, and causing tax liabilities. Fraud scrutiny and cumbersome paperwork exacerbate delays, leading some states (e.g. Haryana) to suspend coverage. Critics warn that without timely, inflation-adjusted payments, Modi’s flagship scheme risks collapse.

articles.title: UK military equipment used by militia accused of genocide found in Sudan, UN told
articles.trailText: Exclusive: two dossiers of material seen by the security council raise questions over export of British arms to the UAE, which has been accused of supplying weapons to paramilitary RSF group
articles.summary: UN-seen dossiers from June 2024 and March 2025 reveal British-made small-arms target systems and Cummins engines for UAE-built Nimr Ajban armoured carriers recovered on Rapid Support Forces (RSF) sites in Sudan. The RSF, accused of genocide, has waged a war killing at least 150,000, displacing 12 million and fueling global hunger. Despite prior allegations of UAE diversion, the UK granted multiple ML14 licences and an open export licence for identical equipment months after evidence of misuse emerged. Critics, including former UN experts and Darfur diaspora leaders, call for urgent UK investigations into arms-export controls and end-use monitoring amid questions over compliance with UN embargoes.

articles.title: Aid cuts in a Senegalese town risk taking away control from its ‘warrior’ women
articles.trailText: Being able to space out their babies is essential to the life and health chances of women in Joal. But now international aid cuts threaten to take away the few choices they have left
articles.summary: In Joal, Senegal’s fragile fishing town of 28,000, women endure back-to-back pregnancies, rising poverty and poor health services. MSI Reproductive Choices’ British-funded Wish 2 outreach (barely restored after UK aid cuts cut its budget from £30m to £6.7m) deploys mobile clinics 22 days a month, fitting IUDs, implants and offering STI and cancer screening to hundreds of women, boosting maternal health, economic prospects and autonomy. Further UK aid reductions risk stripping away this vital lifeline and jeopardising national targets to double contraceptive use by 2028.

articles.title: Cholera is spreading fast, yet it can be stopped. Why haven’t we consigned it to history? | Hakainde Hichilema and Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus
articles.trailText: Vaccine production must be expanded to combat this ancient disease, especially in Africa, but a lack of political will is holding us back
articles.summary: Despite cholera being eliminated in high-income countries, over 6,800 deaths have occurred in 32 nations this year, driven by conflict, poverty and poor sanitation in Africa. The WHO-led Global Task Force on Cholera Control and its 2013 vaccine stockpile (255m doses delivered) rapidly deploy oral vaccines, but demand outstrips supply, forcing a single-dose regimen. Only one manufacturer currently produces at scale; Zambia’s 2024 pact with China’s Jijia aims to build local production. Experts stress that sustainable cholera control hinges on expanding vaccine output and, crucially, political commitment to safe water and sanitation.

articles.title: Secret mining studies and private deals: is a new gold rush quietly starting in El Salvador?
articles.trailText: As the country’s metal mining ban is lifted, rural communities fear a return of the contamination, violence and water shortages that cost so many lives and livelihoods in the past
articles.summary: Ten months after President Nayib Bukele repealed El Salvador’s 2009 metal-mining ban, environmentalists warn a secretive gold rush is under way. The government has classified mining studies as “trade secrets” even as private firms—Titan Resources, Nueva Esperanza, Agrícola San José—and Peruvian “consultants” position around the old El Dorado project. Infrastructure upgrades, armed forces at historic sites and new companies like Citalá Resources underscore fears of reactivation. NGOs face surveillance, politically charged trials and a 30% foreign-donations tax, while rural communities confront acute water scarcity (<1,800 m³ per capita) and arsenic risk. Opponents fear renewed contamination, violence and threats to cultural identity.

articles.title: UK’s biggest weapons firm BAE grounds ‘lifeline’ aircraft delivering food aid
articles.trailText: Exclusive: In the year they announced record profits, Britain’s arms maker has revoked licence to fly for planes taking supplies of food to starving people in South Sudan, Somalia and DRC
articles.summary: BAE Systems, buoyed by £3 bn record profits tied to the Israel–Gaza and Ukraine wars, has voluntarily surrendered the UK CAA type certificate for its Advanced Turbo-Prop (ATP) fleet, grounding EnComm Aviation’s 12 aid aircraft. Between March 2023 and September 2025 these planes delivered 18,677 tonnes of food to South Sudan, Somalia, DRC, Tanzania, CAR and Chad under WFP and DRC contracts now cancelled. EnComm has launched a £187 m negligence suit, as BAE shifts focus to NATO’s 5% defence-spend boost, cutting off a critical lifeline to millions in crisis.

articles.title: Plain rice and little else: life for 120,000 refugees inside Mauritania’s vast camp on Mali’s border
articles.trailText: Over a quarter of a million refugees live in Mbera and nearby villages, and more than half are under 18. But aid cuts mean providing essentials has become even harder
articles.summary: In Mauritania’s Mbera camp on the Mali border some 120,000 refugees rely on dwindling aid after this year’s funding cuts forced WFP to halve monthly food or cash support from 90,000 to 53,000 people and suspend child-nutrition programmes. Over half of the camp’s residents are under 18; many have never seen Mali. Despite schools, a market, bank and biometric registration, families survive on nearly plain rice. Local volunteers run basic healthcare, crop and firefighting initiatives, while leaders like 84-year-old Mohamed Ag Malha maintain routines and hope for return.

articles.title: ‘They told me not to speak out’: the woman who took on China – and won her husband’s freedom
articles.trailText: After fleeing Chinese repression, Uyghurs Idris and Zeynure Hasan thought their family would be safe. But Beijing’s growing influence led to Idris’s arrest and a long battle to be reunited
articles.summary: After fleeing Xinjiang’s crackdown to Istanbul in 2011, Uyghur activists Zeynure Hasan and her husband Idris built careers teaching and translating until China pressured Interpol to issue a red notice. Idris’s July 2021 arrest in Morocco triggered Zeynure’s global campaign—social media updates, Moroccan embassy protests and appeals by human rights NGOs secured Interpol’s notice cancellation and a UN review. Diplomatic pressure from Beijing stalled courts until US secretary of state Marco Rubio quietly brokered Idris’s extraction to Washington in February 2025. By September, Zeynure and their three children obtained Canadian visas, reuniting the family in Toronto.

articles.title: Africa’s children: 20 years on, what happened to the millennium babies?
articles.trailText: In 2005, the Guardian documented the births of 10 babies as a way to tell the story of millions across the continent. We caught up with three of them, finding hardship – and hope
articles.summary: In 2005 the Guardian recorded ten African "millennium babies" to chart progress towards the UN's MDGs; two decades later, three were found in Malawi, Ghana and South Africa, illustrating uneven development. In Malawi, 20-year-old Innocent Smoke works in road-construction testing soil while rent-paying with limited utilities, married with a newborn, and fears job insecurity amid youth unemployment. In Ghana, 19-year-old Hannah Klutsey, with chronic health issues and early school exit, survives as a cake-baking apprentice under crowded conditions. In South Africa, 20-year-old Angel Siyavuya Swartbooi, fresh from rehab, aspires to electrician training from his family's cramped rental, highlighting stalled poverty and job outcomes.

articles.title: Fair Work Agency requires proper resources | Letter
articles.trailText: Letter: Ruth Wilkinson says the workers’ rights watchdog will only succeed with sustained investment and political will
articles.summary: Ruth Wilkinson welcomes Matthew Taylor’s appointment to chair the new Fair Work Agency but warns the single enforcement body will fall short without sustained investment and political will. Chronic underresourcing of HMRC’s national minimum wage unit and the Employment Agency Standards Inspectorate has undermined inspections, investigations and prosecutions, disproportionately impacting insecure and ethnic minority workers. Wilkinson urges national and sectoral strategies to eliminate insecure work, forced labour, modern slavery and child labour, and calls for a long-term employment, financial and human resources plan to ensure the agency can deliver meaningful change.

articles.title: Thailand to let Myanmar refugees work to counter aid cuts and labour shortages
articles.trailText: The move, welcomed by UN, will allow thousands of people living in camps to support themselves and their families
articles.summary: Thailand will allow up to 42,600 Myanmar refugees in nine border camps to obtain work permits, aiming to offset US aid cuts and plug labour gaps after Cambodian workers left. An August labour ministry resolution mandates health screenings and employer vetting, granting refugees formal jobs, access to banking and the ability to support families. UNHCR and aid groups hail the move as a regional precedent that could boost local GDP and foster self-reliance, though language barriers and social integration challenges persist. Agencies will track economic impact and seek to extend rights to urban refugees.

articles.title: Anti-malaria funding cuts could lead to ‘deadliest resurgence ever’, study warns
articles.trailText: Expected reduction in contributions by wealthy countries likely to cost millions of lives and billions in lost growth
articles.summary: Study warns that 20% cuts to Global Fund malaria financing could cause 33 million extra cases, 82 000 deaths and $5.1 billion GDP loss in sub-Saharan Africa by 2030. A full collapse may trigger 525 million new cases, 990 000 deaths (750 000 children) and $83 billion lost GDP. Conversely, the Fund’s $18 billion ask would avert 865 million cases, 1.86 million deaths and yield a $230 billion GDP boost. Extreme weather, crises and rising insecticide/drug resistance heighten the threat. African leaders, Malaria No More UK and philanthropists like Dangote urge G7, private sector and high-net-worth donors to close the funding gap.

articles.title: AI-generated ‘poverty porn’ fake images being used by aid agencies
articles.trailText: Exclusive: Pictures depicting the most vulnerable and poorest people are being used in social media campaigns in the sector, driven by concerns over consent and cost
articles.summary: Researchers and charity workers warn that stock photo sites are flooded with AI-generated images depicting extreme poverty—children in mud, cracked earth, sexual violence survivors—to fuel social media campaigns by major NGOs. Dubbed “poverty porn 2.0” by Arsenii Alenichev of Antwerp’s Institute of Tropical Medicine, these synthetic scenes cost less and bypass consent, but entrench harmful tropes. Adobe Stock and Freepik host dozens of hyperrealist, racialized images under queries like “poverty,” while platforms struggle to police bias. Some charities, like Plan International and the UN, have since withdrawn AI-driven campaigns amid ethical backlash over consent, dignity and the risk of amplifying prejudice.

articles.title: UNAids is set to close in 2026 – four years early. Are experts right to be alarmed?
articles.trailText: The move to shut the agency comes as aid budgets are being slashed, leading to fears that global progress on HIV may be reversed
articles.summary: UN secretary-general proposes sunsetting UNAids by end-2026 amid UN80 cost cuts (halving its 600 staff) and shrinking foreign aid, alarming experts who warn this could reverse recent gains in HIV control. In eastern Europe and central Asia, new infections are up 48% and deaths 32%, with marginalized groups losing vital advocacy and antiretroviral access. UNAids provides unique data on epidemics—67% of 40.8m people with HIV live in Africa—and coordinates funding shifts from donors to domestic budgets. Closure threatens monitoring, targeted prevention (e.g., mother-to-child) and rollout of innovations like lenacapavir, risking resurgence.

articles.title: ‘The loss of education is the loss of the future itself’: Gaza’s children and teachers on two years without school
articles.trailText: With 97% of schools destroyed or damaged, 600,000 children have just begun their third year out of formal education. Three students and a teacher share their stories – and their hopes
articles.summary: After two years of war, 97% of Gaza’s schools lie damaged, leaving 600,000 children without formal education. 12-year-old Juwayriya recalls her bombed classroom and dreams of journalism; teacher Naglaa struggles to keep lessons alive in shelters and online; nine-year-old Sarah mourns lost classmates and her thwarted medical ambitions; seven-year-old Ismail, now in Egypt, faces disrupted learning but clings to hope at an informal refugee school. Amid rubble and displacement, education emerges as an act of defiance and the only path to a future.

articles.title: US anti-vax stance to blame for continent-wide surge in measles, say experts
articles.trailText: The disease was eliminated across the Americas in 2024, but urgent vaccination drives are now under way as cases rise from Mexico to Bolivia after outbreaks farther north
articles.summary: Governments across Latin America are racing to curb a 34-fold rise in measles this year—driven by US outbreaks after anti-vax policies under RFK Jr.—which has ended the Americas’ measles-free status. Pan-American Health Organization reports 11,668 cases across 10 countries, over half in the US and Canada (five deaths), with Mexico hit hardest (4,800 cases, 22 deaths) and Bolivia next (354). Brazil has launched nationwide MMR campaigns, ring vaccination and door-to-door drives; Mexico, Bolivia and others target unvaccinated communities, including Mennonite settlements. MMR coverage stands at 86%, below the 95% herd-immunity threshold, with US misinformation hampering uptake.

articles.title: At 12 an Israeli missile ‘ripped off’ her face. Now Mazyouna is safe in the US – but not all the scars have healed
articles.trailText: The young teenager’s treatment is a rare story of hope from the two-year war in Gaza. With the ceasefire now in effect, she hopes to see her father again
articles.summary: Mazyouna Damoo, 13, lost half her face and two siblings died when an Israeli missile struck her Gaza home in June 2024. After repeated permit rejections, international media coverage secured her evacuation to El Paso, Texas, for multi-stage reconstructive surgery at the children’s hospital. Over a year she’s had cheek, lip and jaw reconstructions, now eats, speaks and attends school, learning English and Spanish. She dreams of becoming a doctor. Her mother preserves Palestinian heritage, while her father remains in Gaza, separated by US visa limits, and her wartime trauma persists.

articles.title: Nursing unions call for UK to back prosecutions for war crimes against health workers
articles.trailText: Calls come as report shows number of health workers killed in conflicts has risen five-fold in less than a decade
articles.summary: Senior nursing and medical bodies, including the RCN and BMA, urge the UK to fully back ICC prosecutions for war crimes targeting health workers after a five-fold rise in conflict-related deaths—from 175 in 2016 to 932 in 2024—according to new RCN data drawing on Insecurity Insights. Attacks and arrests of medical staff in Palestine, Ukraine, Lebanon and Myanmar underscore mounting threats. RCN chief Nicola Ranger and BMA’s Andrew Green demand stronger enforcement of international law and restoration of UK aid to 0.7% of GDP. Testimonies from Afghanistan, Gaza and Myanmar highlight intimidation, resource shortages and impunity-induced trauma.

articles.title: Thousands trapped in El Fasher siege on ‘edge of survival’, says report
articles.trailText: The city – the Sudanese army’s last stronghold in the west of the country – has withstood more than 500 days of attacks by paramilitary RSF
articles.summary: A MedGlobal survey of 900 recent evacuees reveals that after 549 days of RSF encirclement, El Fasher’s 250,000 residents face utter desolation: 90% of homes destroyed or looted, chronic food and water shortages, acute malnutrition in 27.5% of infants and 60% of adolescent girls, and three-quarters displaced multiple times. Indiscriminate RSF artillery and drone strikes on homes, hospitals and shelters—killing dozens—have made the city uninhabitable. The RSF’s raised embankments now fully encircle the city, thwarting escapes and aid deliveries. Communications blackouts block aid; airdrops by Sudan’s army barely suffice. UN and rights bodies decry genocide risks.

articles.title: ‘This generation is defiant’: Gen Z protests set to resume in Morocco despite deaths and arrests
articles.trailText: Activists call for fresh demonstrations this weekend with three people killed and more than 500 reportedly arrested since unrest started in late September
articles.summary: Since late September Morocco’s GenZ212 youth-led protests over underfunded healthcare and education versus World Cup spending have left three reported dead—including 24-year-old filmmaker Abdessamade—and more than 500 arrested. Organizers, mobilizing on Discord (200,000+ subscribers), demand a transparent investigation into his killing. Lawyers say 272 remain detained, including 36 minors, facing unlawful assembly charges that carry up to 10-year sentences. High-profile arrests include rapper Hamza Raid (#FreeKoulchi). Human rights groups call for detainee release; King Mohammed VI pledged rapid reforms but ignored corruption demands. PM Aziz Akhannouch says the government is ready for dialogue. New protests are planned for 18 October.

articles.title: Can Colombia embrace clean energy without damaging the Amazon?
articles.trailText: At the foot of the Andes, a Canadian firm has plans for one of the country’s biggest copper mines, but many say the carbon-rich forests and clean rivers are too high a price to pay
articles.summary: Copper Giant Resources plans to explore some 136,000 ha near Mocoa for up to 2 m tonnes of copper and molybdenum—metals critical for batteries and turbines—but locals, fearing water pollution, ecosystem loss and páramo damage, have blockaded roads and set up a resistance camp. In June, CorpoAmazonia designated 93,000 ha, including parts of the concessions, as an “area of ecological importance,” restricting mining. The dispute highlights tension between President Petro’s drive to secure strategic energy-transition minerals and his promise to safeguard the Colombian Amazon’s biodiversity and carbon-sink function.

articles.title: ‘The universe has opened up for us’: meet the astro-ambassadors who welcome stargazers to the Himalayas
articles.trailText: A tourism initiative in India’s first dark sky reserve has brought new hope to a community as employment means they can stay close to their roots and culture
articles.summary: In Hanle, Ladakh’s new dark sky reserve, 25 locals (18 women) trained as “astro-ambassadors” guide tourists through stargazing, boosting homestay tourism and reviving the community. Controlled lights protect the Indian Astronomical Observatory’s research; villagers earn up to tenfold city salaries and reconnect with Buddhist and pastoral star lore. Annual star parties attract enthusiasts nationwide. Initiatives blend livelihood, heritage and science, but rising tourist vehicles and military camp lighting threaten Hanle’s pristine “Bortle 1” skies, prompting ambassadors to brief commanders on curbing light pollution to safeguard this high-altitude astronomy hub.

articles.title: High youth death rates are an ‘emerging crisis’, global health study warns
articles.trailText: Alcohol, suicide and injuries driving rises among teenagers and young adults despite overall rates falling, authors say
articles.summary: The 2025 Global Burden of Disease study in Lancet, compiling 300,000 sources and 16,500 researchers, warns of an ‘emerging crisis’: rising death rates among 10–29 year-olds. In North and Latin America spikes stem from drugs, alcohol and suicide tied to surging anxiety and depression; in sub-Saharan Africa excess youth mortality is driven by infectious diseases, injuries and maternal causes. Overall life expectancy rebounded post-COVID to 76.3 years for women, yet chronic diseases now account for two-thirds of ill health and half of all disease is preventable, prompting calls for youth-centered, integrated health investments.

articles.title: Gaza PhD student ‘heartbroken’ as family blocked from entering the UK
articles.trailText: Manar al-Houbi’s husband and children refused entry despite her winning a scholarship to cover tuition fees, living costs and housing for them all
articles.summary: Gaza PhD candidate Manar al-Houbi secured a fully funded Cara scholarship at the University of Glasgow covering tuition, housing and living costs for her and her dependants. Despite visa rules allowing full-time PhD students to bring family, the UK FCDO refused entry for her husband and children, citing UK immigration policy, while Deputy PM David Lammy blamed Israeli exit permissions—denied by Israel’s COGAT. Displaced in a Khan Younis tent after their Rafah home was bombed, al-Houbi plans research on media’s role in combating violence against women and hopes to teach in Gaza post-PhD. Cara and Scottish ministers are pressing the UK government to secure her family’s evacuation immediately.

articles.title: Torture, blackmail, extortion: the dangers of queer online dating in Ghana
articles.trailText: Homophobic attacks on LGBTQ+ community rising as criminals, using social media to lure victims, are emboldened by political debate
articles.summary: Criminal gangs in Ghana exploit dating apps like Grindr, TikTok and Facebook to lure gay men, bisexual men and transgender women into isolated locations for assault, blackmail and extortion. Often armed with footage of torture—such as trans chef Delali’s three-hour beating or the viral ‘Kofi’ attack—they threaten to expose victims under a climate of heightened homophobia stoked by an anti-gay bill debated in parliament and election campaigns. Rightify Ghana documents a threefold rise in reported abuses in 2024, but many incidents remain unreported amid police indifference. Viral videos and AI filters fuel further violence, experts warn.

articles.title: US ‘undermining global health’ by threatening to strip funding from aid projects that do not fit its political agenda
articles.trailText: Trump administration reported to be planning expansion of ‘global gag rule’ to halt any initiatives promoting diversity, equity and inclusion
articles.summary: Trump administration plans to extend its ‘global gag rule’ (Mexico City policy) to bar or punish any foreign governments, NGOs and multilateral organisations promoting abortion, “gender ideology” or diversity, equity and inclusion (DEI), threatening to cut all US funding. For the first time, UN agencies and foreign governments face “hard choices” between DEI programmes—such as HIV prevention among young women and gender-sensitive health services—and critical aid. Experts warn the expansion infringes sovereignty, risks clinic closures, increased deaths, violence and destabilises decades of health partnerships. Campaigners urge governments to reject conditional US aid to preserve human rights and public health.

articles.title: ‘I have searched and searched for help’: the Sudanese women left alone to live hand to mouth in Chad’s desert camps
articles.trailText: As the war in Sudan pushes more people across the border, malnutrition is on the rise in Chad’s remote settlements where 86% of the refugees are women and children
articles.summary: Since 2023, 878,000 Sudanese refugees—86% women and children—have streamed into remote desert camps in eastern Chad, where scarce water (≈9 L/day), minimal rations and no work have driven rising malnutrition and maternal emergencies. With a single MSF hospital in Metche and one ambulance for tens of thousands, women reach care dangerously late—fueling ruptured uteri and fatalities—and malnutrition wards swell. Slashed international aid (only 69% of UN appeals met) threatens further cuts to food and education.

articles.title: Fast-fashion recycling: how ‘the castoff capital of the world’ is making Indian factory workers sick
articles.trailText: Reports of lung disease, skin conditions and even cancer are rising in Panipat, which recycles 1 million tonnes of textile waste a year
articles.summary: Panipat’s 20,000 recycling mills process around 1 million tonnes of discarded garments a year, shredding global fast-fashion waste into ‘shoddy’ yarn. Thousands of poorly ventilated workstations expose at least 300,000 laborers to airborne lint and microplastics, fueling chronic coughs, COPD, skin conditions and cancer risks. With minimal safety gear and no childcare, workers like Neerma Devi face irreversible lung damage across generations. Simultaneously, 600+ legal and illegal bleaching and dyeing units dump toxic effluents into local drains and groundwater, sparking widespread skin ailments and non-communicable diseases amid weak enforcement.

articles.title: This Patagonian village has glacier-fed rivers and majestic scenery. The only problem? Sewage
articles.trailText: El Chaltén is a paradise for hikers. But the seasonal influx of tourists stretches the sanitation infrastructure to breaking point – and even a legal victory has not provided a solution
articles.summary: In Argentina’s El Chaltén, a surge of up to 10,000 daily hikers overwhelms sewage plants, sending untreated waste and antibiotic-resistant E. coli into glacier-fed Fitz Roy and Las Vueltas rivers. After a 2023 court victory under the Escazú treaty, authorities pledged to upgrade treatment by January 2025, yet pollution persists. Community group Guardians of El Chaltén Basin and biologists documented multiresistant bacteria near plant outfalls, prompting new lawsuits and oversight committees. Locals demand robust enforcement, infrastructure expansion and sustained water quality monitoring in this Unesco heritage park.

articles.title: Seeing double: the wooden carvings that celebrate the Yorùbá’s unique connection to twins
articles.trailText: The Ìbejì Project is resurrecting interest in the traditional art of the Yorùbá people, who have one of the highest rates of twin births in the world
articles.summary: After acquiring a pair of traditional Yorùbá twin statuettes (ère ìbejì) in 2022, Nigerian curator Kayode Adegbola launched the Ìbejì Project in 2023 to revive the spiritual art form tied to the region’s high twin birth rate. Historically, Yorùbá families carved and cared for ère ìbejì to honor twins’ spirits, but museum collections scattered originals abroad. Adegbola collects, exhibits and pairs them with contemporary artists exploring duality, absence and continuity. His advocacy has reignited local interest, prompted new acquisitions and plans for a scholarly book, aiming to reposition ère ìbejì as a living, global cultural heritage.

articles.title: Trouble brewing: Maya people in Yucatán fear new Heineken plant’s thirst for water
articles.trailText: Indigenous groups in Mexico opposed to the planned brewery say families already have little access to water – and that their way of life is also under threat
articles.summary: Indigenous Maya in Yucatán are mobilizing against Heineken’s new $2.75bn brewery in Kanasín, warning its annual 400m-litre output may deplete the sacred Cenote Ring aquifer, already strained after water availability halved since 2003 and 121,000 locals lacked potable water in 2020. Heineken promises 2 litres of water per litre of beer and 2,500 jobs, but activists contest these claims, noting past contamination from pig farms and a Modelo brewery, that only 3% of state wastewater is treated, fear untreated effluent pollution, highlight lack of ‘free, prior and informed consent’, and warn of cultural erosion, gentrification and rights violations.

articles.title: ‘We called ourselves the lifeboat crew’: how fired USAID workers launched a rescue project ‘to save as many babies as we can’
articles.trailText: After the Trump administration closed the organisation down, a group of former staff secured new funding for almost 80 programmes, benefiting an estimated 40 million people
articles.summary: After the Trump administration shuttered USAID and forced mass layoffs, former agency staff formed the Project Resource Optimization (Pro) “lifeboat crew” to salvage vital overseas aid. By vetting cancelled programmes for cost-effective, life-saving impact, they matched 79 projects across more than 30 countries with $110m in new funding from anonymous philanthropies and individuals—benefiting 40m people, many under five. After an initial anchor grant, they expanded outreach to multiple donors. Operating under the Center for Global Development, Pro aims to “buy time” for NGOs, not replace long-term solutions. Three projects regained USAID support; nine could not be saved. Example: Alima’s malnutrition, maternity and vaccination services in Mali.

articles.title: The families of Syria’s disappeared are asking for the truth. Our country cannot rebuild until we have it | Wafa Mustafa
articles.trailText: Over 160,000 people, including my father, were abducted by the Assad regime. The country’s new commission for the missing must be inclusive and independent to restore our trust
articles.summary: Wafa Mustafa recounts her 11-year ordeal after her father, Ali Mustafa, was abducted by Assad’s forces in July 2013—one among 160,000+ documented enforced disappearances. Trapped in “ambiguous loss,” families lack bodies, records or closure. After the regime’s December 2024 collapse opened prisons, survivors still found no trace. Mustafa calls on Syria’s interim government to end disappearances and sectarian violence, and to establish an inclusive, independent National Commission for the Missing—family-led to guarantee truth, justice and rebuild trust. She stresses Syrians, not foreign powers, must sustain this fight until every loved one’s fate is known.

articles.title: Crowded camps, stagnant water and not enough doctors: first the floods, now disease stalks millions in Pakistan
articles.trailText: As the waters recede, a surge in cases of cholera, diarrhoea, malaria and dengue has compounded the misery of people who have already seen their homes and crops disappear
articles.summary: UN estimates floods since June in Pakistan’s Punjab have affected over 6M and killed nearly 1,000 (250 children), displacing 2.5M and damaging 15% of homes in Multan (5M pop, 3,720 sq km). Flood camps lack sanitation, clean water and medical staff; government reports 56,415 camp beds with six fixed clinics and 28 mobile units, yet many have seen no doctor. Local hospitals report doubling of cholera, malaria, dengue and diarrhoea. WHO notes an 87% surge in vector-borne diseases (June–Aug). Women and children face inadequate latrines, no menstrual supplies and security risks, worsening post-flood health crises.

articles.title: Women behind the lens: ‘I thought, who is this woman? I need to know her’
articles.trailText: Indian artist Indu Antony was mesmerised when she first saw 78-year-old Cecilia and has put her at the heart of a project that interrogates women’s safety in public spaces and celebrates friendship
articles.summary: Indian artist Indu Antony’s Cecilia’ed project centers 78-year-old Cecilia—a vibrant figure defying age and gender norms—as a ‘celebrity’ in public-space interventions across Bengaluru, India’s third most dangerous city for women. Antony documented Cecilia in 100 intimate photos, then used police data to pinpoint unsafe streets, staging ribbon-cuttings, distributing Cecilia-branded matchboxes and running neighbourhood workshops and male-space screenings. Cecilia’ed fuses feminist geography with playful activism, reclaiming urban spaces, shifting power dynamics and celebrating female friendship, resilience and visibility through community-led art.

articles.title: ‘Will my baby be born in a tent? Will it have food?’: what it’s like to be pregnant in Gaza
articles.trailText: The World Health Organization has warned that more than 40% of pregnant women in the Gaza Strip are malnourished. Here, Nour Ziad al-Batsh, who is expecting her third child in March, describes her daily struggle to find food and healthcare
articles.summary: Nour Ziad al-Batsh, expecting her third child in Gaza, describes life under siege: 40% of pregnant women are malnourished, and extreme fatigue has triggered bleeding, dizziness and tremors. Doctors Without Borders classed her high-risk, yet hospitals lack capacity for her critical need. Displacement and relentless bombings destroyed her home and her husband’s optical practice; she now lives with two malnourished children in a tent near Nuseirat without water, power or steady food. Sky-rocketing prices, 50% bank-exchange fees and imminent hunger fuel her fear over finding basic care and nourishment for her baby.

articles.title: As US warships prowl the Caribbean, our region must hold fast against Trump’s gaslighting
articles.trailText: American attacks have killed more than 14 people they claim were drug traffickers in our waters. Now our islands are at risk of being dragged into a manufactured conflict we are ill-equipped to endure
articles.summary: US warships have launched missile strikes on alleged drug boats off Venezuela, killing over 14 people, while Trinidad and Tobago granted access without Caricom approval. Washington casts the Caribbean as a narco-transit hub to obscure US drug demand and secure oil interests, endangering fishers, tourism and fragile economies. Venezuela has mobilized its navy and regional solidarity is fraying under Trump’s election-driven spectacle. Caribbean leaders call for diplomacy, evidence-based operations and unity to prevent small states from becoming collateral damage.

articles.title: ‘She didn’t realise how dangerous it was’: London-bound student held in China over Tibet support
articles.trailText: Zhang Yadi was due to begin a degree in the UK but the activist vanished on holiday amid tensions over Dalai Lama
articles.summary: Zhang Yadi, 22, a Chinese Buddhist student and Tibetan rights activist who wrote for the pro-Tibet newsletter Chinese Youth Stand For Tibet, vanished in late July while touring Tibetan areas of Sichuan. She had been due to start an anthropology graduate degree at SOAS, London. Beijing now holds her in Changsha on “inciting separatism” charges—punishable by up to 15 years—under a new law targeting overseas ethnic “disunity.” Friends, family and human rights groups allege her activism abroad and the Dalai Lama’s defiance prompted her detention, and there has been no contact since her arrest.

articles.title: ‘It’s more than martial arts – we teach courage’: the Afghan sisters honing karate skills in Iran
articles.trailText: The three women live in exile where, despite an increase in deportations and rising hostility towards migrants, they use sport to empower women
articles.summary: Shokoufeh Jafari (29) and her sisters Maryam (23) and Mandana (20) fled Afghanistan in 1998 and now train Kyokushin karate in exile in Shiraz, Iran. Encouraged by their former military officer father, they rose to represent Afghanistan internationally, winning medals at the 2019 Asian Kyokushin Championship. After the Taliban banned women’s sports, they opened a dojo for Afghan girls, teaching martial arts and self-belief amid intensified deportations (800,000 Afghans expelled June–July 2025) and hostility in Iran. Lacking citizenship and facing prejudice, they preserve Afghan culture at home while pursuing law, genetic research and robotics, and advocating women’s rights.

articles.title: How the world’s taste for soya is eating Brazil’s Amazon
articles.trailText: Cultivation of the crop has made a few wealthy but at a huge cost to untouched forest as it spreads across vast areas of former wilderness
articles.summary: In Brazil’s Amazon, soya cultivation has surged across nine states, driven by global demand—particularly China’s feed market—making Brazil the top exporter with 51.5m tonnes in early 2025. While agribusiness bolsters GDP and rural jobs, expansion breaches deforestation moratoria, fuels legal battles, threatens biodiversity and indigenous lands, and clogs highways like BR-364. EU deforestation-free import rules and a 2006 soya moratorium curbed some clearing, but post-2008 forest loss and secondary road sprawl continue. Pioneering crop science and tax incentives sustain growth, but experts warn unchecked soya fronts imperil climate stability, watersheds and vulnerable communities.

articles.title: ‘I feel broken’: hardship bites for thousands of South Sudanese stranded and unable to get home
articles.trailText: Renk, an onward travel hub for people fleeing war in Sudan, has become a bottleneck as aid cuts leave displaced families exposed and in need
articles.summary: Since April 2023, over 800,000 South Sudanese have fled Sudan’s war to Renk, a transit hub on the White Nile, where IOM’s relocation programme moved 250,000 people until June 2025. Funding cuts tied to a US aid freeze forced suspension of the scheme, leaving 9,000+ returnees stranded in overcrowded camps with scarce food, water and shelter. Families like 66-year-old Musa Rajab have spent their cash grants on tarpaulins or sold possessions for essentials. The IOM and gov’t urge swift international support; recent UK funds moved 915 people but capacity remains overstretched.

articles.title: ‘A donkey cart out of El Fasher costs more than a new car’: how 500 days under siege is tearing the city apart
articles.trailText: North Darfur’s capital has been under siege for 500 days, its people facing starvation, blockade and bombardment, with scant hope of relief, says Sudanese political scientist Sarra Majdoub
articles.summary: El Fasher, North Darfur’s capital, has endured a 500-day siege by the RSF since May 2024. Trenches crisscross flooded streets as civilians shelter from daily dawn-to-dusk shelling. Drones patrol the skies, intensifying fear. RSF fortifications block all but one exit—a perilous, extortionate trek to Tawila, where a donkey cart costs more than a car. Starvation looms: millet fetches $100 for 2 kg, communal kitchens offer one meagre meal, volunteers treat shrapnel wounds with scant supplies. With no aid and external military support bolstering the RSF, El Fasher’s survival hangs by a thread.

articles.title: US refuses to back UN declaration on noncommunicable diseases
articles.trailText: General assembly backs new targets on cancer, diabetes and heart disease but Robert F Kennedy Jr objects
articles.summary: At the UN General Assembly, US health secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr. unexpectedly vetoed the fourth political declaration on noncommunicable diseases (NCDs) and mental health, claiming it advanced “gender ideology” and abortion rights despite no such language in the text. The declaration, backed by most member states, sets new global targets to tackle heart disease, cancer, diabetes and chronic respiratory illnesses responsible for 43 million deaths annually—80% of which are preventable—and urges affordable medicines and integration of mental health and renal and oral health. Proposals for higher taxes on tobacco, alcohol and sugary drinks were stripped under industry pressure. Only 19 countries remain on track to cut premature NCD mortality by one-third by 2030. Mexico plans to hike its sugar tax by 40% to fund health programmes as obesity and diabetes soar.

articles.title: They fled war and sexual violence and found a safe space in Athens. Then the aid cuts hit
articles.trailText: Thirty women and their children found themselves out on the streets when their shelter closed. It was a direct result of US and European governments slashing their aid budgets
articles.summary: On 29 May, METAdrasi’s women’s shelter in Athens closed without warning after US and European aid cuts—triggered by President Trump’s January 2025 freeze on US foreign assistance—forced the charity to shutter the facility. Thirty refugee women and five children—including Ukrainians and survivors of sexual violence from the Congo—were evicted, left sleeping in parks and churches. One woman clung to the refuge before police removed her. NGOs warn that halved UNHCR funding and EU spending cuts have gutted Greece’s protection system, shifting aid priorities from psychological support to bare survival and imperiling the entire humanitarian network.

articles.title: When I was married at 13 I was told refusal would end in my death. Now girls in Iraq as young as nine face the same fate
articles.trailText: A new law legitimises violence and entrenches control over the bodies of millions of women and girls like me
articles.summary: Drawing on her own ordeal, Hala Abdullah recounts forced marriage at 13 to a 29-year-old groom in Iraq, where family intimidation, beatings and death threats extinguished her childhood. Subjected to daily violence and emotional manipulation—kissed against her will, pressured for intimacy—she experienced trauma bonding, shame and guilt. Iraq’s new law allowing marriages from age nine, she warns, legitimises such violence, stripping girls of autonomy, normalising control over their bodies and childhoods.

articles.title: Unsafe abortions and no antenatal care: aid cuts hit women hardest in one of Africa’s poorest countries
articles.trailText: Mobile clinics in rural Malawi that provided pregnancy checks as well as vaccinations and TB tests have been lost
articles.summary: The abrupt suspension of a $28m USAID maternal health outreach programme in January 2025 has shuttered mobile clinics in remote Salima district, cutting cervical cancer screening, antenatal appointments, vaccinations, TB testing and family-planning services. Women now travel over 25 miles on dirt tracks, saving scarce funds for transport, while unintended pregnancies, unsafe abortions and maternal deaths rise. The loss of Momentum Tikweze Umoyo—part of Trump’s US aid cuts—threatens previous gains in infant immunisation, TB detection and reducing maternal mortality in one of Africa’s poorest, climate-vulnerable nations.

articles.title: ‘An eye for an eye’: some Duterte death squad members unrepentant as he awaits ICC trial
articles.trailText: Up to 30,000 alleged drug users and dealers were slaughtered in the Philippines’ so-called drug war, but on Manila’s streets some of their killers still believe they did the right thing
articles.summary: In Manila, four current and former Philippine police officers who participated in Duterte’s 2016–22 drug war death squads—allegedly responsible for up to 30,000 extrajudicial killings—tell the Guardian they remain unrepentant, justifying “an eye for an eye” against alleged dealers, ordering fake “nanlaban” reports and staging scenes. They describe boozy debriefs, superstition-driven guilt rituals at church and high public approval for Duterte—63% in recent polls—despite his ICC trial at The Hague for crimes against humanity. Victims’ families demand justice amid slow domestic probes.

articles.title: ‘We will never, ever escape’: inside the ever-tightening siege of the Sudanese city of El Fasher
articles.trailText: For 500 days, 260,000 people have been trapped by the paramilitary RSF. While political progress stalls, those who attempt escape are killed and those who remain inside are starving. Experts believe the city will soon fall and the endgame has begun
articles.summary: For over 500 days the Rapid Support Forces (RSF) have encircled El Fasher, trapping 260,000 people—half of them children—amid daily bombardment and starvation. A ragtag mix of volunteers like 75-year-old Mariam Abdelghaffa and rebel commander Sāra Bakhit have repelled some 228 assaults, yet medicine, food and aid convoys remain blocked—allegedly due to UAE influence despite US and UN pressure. Intelligence warnings of ethnic cleansing if the RSF captures this last Darfur bastion grow urgent as political impasse deepens, humanitarian pauses fail and the city’s fall looms.

articles.title: ‘It kept our spirits alive’: Taliban’s internet blackout leaves girls in despair
articles.trailText: Many Afghan women and girls can no longer communicate or study online after the internet is cut off in 12 provinces
articles.summary: On 15 September the Taliban severed fibre-optic internet in 12 northern and southern provinces—including Balkh, Kandahar, Helmand and Herat—ostensibly to ‘prevent immorality’, effectively silencing the lifeline of online education for tens of thousands of Afghan women and girls barred from secondary schools. Students like 17-year-old Marjaneh and Maryam saw their unlimited home wifi cut overnight, resorting to expensive, patchy mobile data often inaccessible to unmarried women. Platforms such as the Online Women’s University (17,000 enrolments) and evening Google Meet law and journalism classes now collapse, stripping students not only of lessons but of community and hope, threatening scholarships abroad and essential vocational training.

articles.title: Death by aid cuts: how a decision in the US led to the loss of a mother in Yemen
articles.trailText: While the Trump administration claims no one will die over the axing of its overseas development budgets, aid agencies say the action will cost at least 3 million lives. Fatima and her baby were among the first
articles.summary: In May, in rural al-Masilah, Yemen, Fatima, pregnant with her third child, died during obstructed labor after her local clinic’s referral to Sayhut hospital for a likely C-section was refused due to lack of diesel and funding. US cuts to UNFPA emergency obstetric support under President Trump halted medicines, fuel and staff at Sayhut. An 1.5-hour ambulance transfer to al-Raidah proved fatal when her uterus ruptured en route. UNFPA warns 1.5m women have lost life-saving reproductive care and maternal deaths will surge without resumed aid.

articles.title: Illness, animal deaths and water shortages: life inside Chile’s polluted ‘sacrifice zones’
articles.trailText: Allegations of environmental breaches dog Anglo American’s mining operations. Now the company has been given the go-ahead for plans that communities say risk disaster
articles.summary: In Catemu, residents report blue smelter fumes, high particulate and sulfur dioxide levels, asthma and convulsions in children; 2019 government data flagged pollution breaches; a decontamination plan remains unimplemented. Near El Soldado, farmers allege toxic tailings dam releases cause livestock deaths, yellow river water and grey dust; regulators fined the company for water misuse affecting 5,000 residents. At Los Bronces, planned glacier-subterranean expansion and a 25-mile waste pipeline near Santiago draw disaster risk warnings. Anglo American asserts compliance, emission controls and awards, but faces ongoing charges and legal challenges.

articles.title: ‘Send your daughters or you get no aid’: the Taliban are making religious schools girls’ only option
articles.trailText: Food handouts and employment are increasingly tied to Afghan families’ agreement to strict Islamic education
articles.summary: After excluding girls from secondary schools and universities, the Taliban built over 21,000 madrasas by end-2024—50 more since September across 11 provinces. Families face coercion and incentives—'send daughters or get no food aid'—while mullahs earn salaries per pupil. Qualified female teachers are sacked and replaced by teenage madrasa graduates; curricula focus solely on Quran memorization, Taliban law and gender roles in Pashto, with no maths or science. International aid and school supplies are diverted. Girls drop out of public schools, and madrasa certificates become the only recognized qualification, erasing career ambitions.

articles.title: ‘A defining moment’: Trinidad and Tobago at a crossroads as oil runs out
articles.trailText: Fossil fuels made the nation prosperous but as reserves dwindle, do they drill deeper, even as the Caribbean feels the heat of the climate crisis, or shift to a greener economy?
articles.summary: Trinidad and Tobago’s oil output has plunged from 278,000 barrels a day in the 1970s to under 54,000 today, driving a 48% drop in energy revenues to $14.7 bn, while non-energy receipts rose 26% to $32.7 bn. High public debt (64.5% of GDP), low growth (1.7% in 2024) and shrinking gas reserves (around ten years at current rates) force a choice between deep-water drilling deals with ExxonMobil (potential $21.7 bn investment) and nascent green strategies: 4 m tonnes of green hydrogen and 57 GW offshore wind by 2065. Economists warn that without diversification into tourism, agriculture, finance and renewables, the country risks ecological harm, climate shocks and faltering social gains.

articles.title: Kenya’s Turkana people genetically adapted to live in harsh environment, study suggests
articles.trailText: Research which began with conversations round a campfire and went on to examine 7m gene variants shows how people survive with little water and a meat-rich diet
articles.summary: The Turkana Health and Genomics Project sequenced 367 whole genomes and analyzed over 7 million variants in Kenya’s Turkana pastoralists, identifying eight regions under positive selection—most notably the kidney-expressed gene STC1, linked to dehydration resilience and purine metabolism on their meat-rich diet. Adaptations dating to aridification 5,000 years ago explain low gout incidence despite high purine intake and 90% dehydration rates. However, urban migrants show altered gene expression predisposing them to hypertension and obesity. Co-produced with community elders, the study offers insights for tailored health programs and climate-driven human evolution.

articles.title: ‘Other countries would have preserved it’: Yemenis mourn the demolition of historic mud-brick palaces
articles.trailText: In the city of Tarim, colourful mansions built by the city’s merchants are being knocked down as the war-torn nation cannot afford to maintain them
articles.summary: Amid Yemen’s war and funding shortages, Tarim’s colourful merchant-built mud-brick palaces—including Abdul Rahman Bin Sheikh al-Kaf’s interwar mansion—are being torn down or left to collapse. Local journalist Haddad Musaied filmed the ruins as owner Mohammed al-Kaf blamed the government for failing to finance repairs. These unique Hadrami structures, infused with southeast Asian motifs, anchor Tarim’s Sufi and missionary heritage, recognised by ICESCO in 2010 and on Yemen’s Unesco tentative list. Cash-strapped antiquities officials can only document dilapidation, lacking resources to save these endangered monuments.

articles.title: On the road with the minister tasked with defending Britain’s painful aid cuts to Ghana
articles.trailText: Jenny Chapman is shown the impact of her government’s ever-diminishing assistance on her first trip accompanied by the media since taking charge of development
articles.summary: On her first media-accompanied visit as development minister, Labour’s Jenny Chapman toured Ghana to inspect the impact of UK aid cuts—slashed from 0.5% to 0.3% of GNI by 2027—and saw how programmes like an 85% UK-funded catch-up class risk collapse. UK aid to Ghana fell from £47.1 m in 2019 to £13.9 m in 2023 amid reprioritisation toward Ukraine, Sudan and Gaza. Chapman touted successes such as a HMRC tax partnership yielding £100 m annually, biotech grants and Global Fund health support, while conceding “less money for traditional programming” and facing widespread criticism.

articles.title: ‘We pray a visa comes before death’: Gaza’s injured children left in limbo
articles.trailText: Mariam, Nasser and Ahmed were evacuated from the warzone but are now stranded in an Egyptian hospital that cannot treat their life-threatening injuries after Trump’s sudden ban on Palestinians entering the US
articles.summary: Mariam Sabbah (9), Nasser al-Najjar (18) and Ahmed Duweik (10)—evacuated from Gaza to an Egyptian hospital—are stranded after the US paused visas for Palestinians, following a far-right campaign under Trump’s watch. All three need specialist reconstructive surgery for severe war injuries—Mariam’s amputated arm and pelvic trauma, Najjar’s disfigured face and jaw, Ahmed’s amputations and nerve damage—but Egypt lacks the expertise. Since October 2023 over 7,600 patients (5,300 children) were evacuated abroad yet 700 died awaiting approval. NGOs warn further delays risk deterioration and plea for visa approvals before death comes first.
